nodes.text: An agent seeks to maximize the time-average growth rate of their wealth iff their preferences on stochastic wealth processes are representable by a unique ergodic transformation f satisfying a set of axioms
Preferences over stochastic wealth processes X are modeled as a complete preorder satisfying consistency (completeness, transitivity, reflexivity)
Add continuity and independence (mixture space structure and Archimedean property) to preferences to obtain a linear functional representation L on mixture space

Introduce monotonicity and the Ergodicity Axiom (EA): processes x preferred to x' iff the long-run time-average growth of f(x) exceeds that of f(x'), yielding a representation where preference ordering equals expected value of transformed process and expectation equals time average

Main theorem (Ergodic vNM): preferences satisfying axioms 3.1-3.5 are representable by E[f(xt)] with E[f(xt)] = lim_{t->infty} (f(xt)-f(x0))/t, so f is an ergodic transformation extracting time coefficient
Mixture Space Theorem: with consistency and independence on mixture space X there exists a linear functional L such that x >= x' iff L(x) >= L(x') (intermediate step to Ergodic vNM)
Empirical motivation: Copenhagen Experiment (CE) and Meder et al. (2021) report subjects adapt utility to render wealth changes ergodic (logarithmic for multiplicative, linear for additive dynamics)
Critique and comparison context: skeptics argue EE should be compared to multi-period expected utility and dynamic ambiguity aversion, motivating axiomatization and normative comparison

Construction method for ergodic transformation: for Ito process dx = a(x)dt + b(x)dW find f with df = alpha dt + beta dW (constant coefficients) using Ito's lemma, leading to condition a(x) = (alpha/beta) b(x) + b(x) b'(x)/2

Example result: for dynamic dx = x^gamma[1 + gamma/2 x^{gamma-1} dt + dW] the ergodic transformation solving f'(x)=1/b(x) yields f(x) = x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma)+C (power form), so the usual CRRA utility appears as the ergodic transformation

Interpretation claim: when f is the ergodic transformation, maximizing expected f equals maximizing long-run growth, and the parameter gamma in f(x)=x^{1-gamma}/(1-gamma) should not be interpreted directly as psychological risk aversion but as determined by dynamics

Limitations and extensions: framework assumes objective known dynamics, infinite time limit (pre-asymptotic life concerns), and omits preferences for early resolution and model misspecification; suggests extension to ambiguity aversion and finite-time convergence preferences

Conclusion: axiomatization furnishes clear normative conditions for Ergodicity Economics, clarifies when EE deviates from classical EUT, and provides a path to compare CE empirically to multi-period EUT and to incorporate additional behavioral features in future work
